messageBody:
Hi Craig,

To do what you want to do you need to install a custom xsl stylesheet
for <junitreport>. To do this follow the steps below. Now that I've
written them out, its a bit of an epic but stay with me and it will work ;-)

Cheers,
-Brendan
http://www.cenqua.com

1. extract the default stylesheets from ANT_HOME/lib/ant-junit.jar. The
two files you need are:
org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/optional/junit/xsl/junit-frames.xsl
org/apache/tools/ant/taskdefs/optional/junit/xsl/junit-noframes.xsl

2. save these two files into a subdir of your project dir, eg
PROJECT_HOME/junitstyle:

junitstyle/junit-frames.xsl
junitstyle/junit-noframes.xsl

3. tell <junitreport> where to load its stylesheets in your build.xml:

<junitreport ... styledir="./junitstyle"/>

4. edit the stylesheets (or just the one you use).

Find the template in the file called "display-failures":
<xsl:template name="display-failures">

a few lines into this template, you'll see

<xsl:value-of select="@message" />

you need to change this to

<xsl:value-of select="@message" disable-output-escaping="yes"/>

5. all done. save the stylesheets and give it a whirl. HTML formatting
in fail() and assert*() messages should now be preserved.


Craig Dickson wrote:
> It appears that the XML formatter used by the Ant JUnit task (correctly)
> encodes any '<' or '>' characters that appear in the output of the test
> method before including it in the XML output file.
>
> For example, if in my test method I call
> fail("<b>big problem</b>");
>
> then in the XML document, this will appear as:
> <testcase name=" ... " class=" ... ">
> <failure message="<b>big problem</b>" type=" ... ">
> ...
> </failure>
> </testcase>
>
> Now, when the <junit-report> Ant task processes this file, it copies the
> encoding over to the HTML document, so that when the report is viewed in
> a browser the <b> tag is just interpreted as regular text instead of markup.
>
> Anyone know how to get markup from a JUnit test across to the output
> from the <junit-reprot> task?
>
> Thanks
>
